Hi Frank,

As Dianne said it may boil down to faith. I am also a firm belei=
ver in
JUnit especially if you use Test-driven development. My experience
t=
ells me that it does make a significant difference especially if you
want t=
o add lots of new features all the time.

My experience is mainly from come=
rcial projects and lately from
participating in the development of rMock ht=
tp://rmock.sf.net

Let me put it this way:

If you don't have the tests to =
prove that your system works, adding
new features, and knowing you didn't b=
reak anything that used to work,
is way harder than if you have them.

Toda=
y I would actually think twice if I knew that a comercial product
was not p=
roperly unit-tested before buying it, I would not trust its
quality since I=
 have seen the difference in my code and other peoples
code when changing t=
owards TDD.


As a concrete example of where my faith in unit tests comes f=
rom:

Some years ago I was a tech-lead (coding tech-lead) for a web-based
a=
pplication, one of many in a portal. "my" application was supposed to
go li=
ve together with a similar application (in terms of complexity)
developed b=
y another company.
I had managed to get the customer interested in TDD (tha=
t to them was
the same as having automated unit tests) and they had agreed =
to let me
"prove my point" on this project well aware that this might take =
a
little bit more time since we were all inexperienced in TDD (they were
wi=
lling to take the risk since they saw a potential benefit in higher
quality=
 and less bugs since going live in that system was
traditionally tedious an=
d error-prone. A bug in a component requires a
new turn in that procedure s=
o it is better if it works when they go
live ;))

The development was no pi=
cknick, TDD is not a silver bullet and you
make mistakes while you learn ho=
w to master it. This application was
no exception.
After we went live only =
2 bugs have ever been discovered and none of
them serious. The other applic=
ation had more than 100 reported bugs of
different levels chriticality the =
first week.

I attribute this difference mainly to the fact that we had uni=
t-tests
and the others didn't (It would be tempting to think that we were
s=
imply that much better and smarter but realistically: our choice of
enginer=
ing approach was better in this case). It is also interesting
to note that =
we did not need more time to finish our application than
the other team did=
, I think that this is bvecause they spent more time
in word than we did an=
d we spent more time in code than they did,
relying more on our testcases t=
o drive the design and acting on the
feedback we got from our tests. In fac=
t our server side components
were live 1 week before theirs.


Do I think u=
nit testing takes more time? Yes and no:

Yes - because there is more code =
to write, and in the beginning there
is a learning curve. I would say that =
you would experience a drop in
productivity the first couple of months unti=
l you get the "hang of it"
TDD is a new way of thinking but it is worth lea=
rning. I think TDD is
almost as big of a change as it is to change from pro=
cvedural oriented
thinking to OO thinking, you never stop learning and it w=
ill take you
years to master it (although you will get benefits from it muc=
h earlier)

No - because you tend to write less "unused code" simply becaus=
e
having to have a test for every line of code you write makes you
reluctan=
t to do "might be good if I want to do this in the future"
kind of design s=
tunts. This also comes from the knowledge that
changing the code to support=
 those "might be good to haves" is
straight forward, if you have the tests,=
 when they change from "might
be good" to "are necesary".
Less "might be go=
od to haves" alsoe leaves less production code to
maintain wich saves some =
effort, I don't remember who said that he
"would rather have his developers=
 surf the web than adding code that
did not immediately provide any value".=
 An interesting thought.

No - Because you tend to do less bug-hunting sinc=
e your code usually
works.

No - Because your design, with TDD, tends to be=
 simpler, more to the
point and better when you drive it with tests (when y=
ou learn how to
do that, before that you will just have very complicated te=
sts and the
same design).

Yes - Because if you have not been doing test-dr=
iven development so
far your design will likely be hard to test until you r=
emedy that. To
fix that is time well spent since a testable design is usual=
ly an
extendable one and when you have your tests you will see that you can=

add new features faster than you thought were possible. But
productivity w=
ill no doubt drop until you have spent some time
refactoring for testabilit=
y (and fixing what you break/try to prevent
to break stuff while doing that=
 since you have no tests at the moment)

I am not saing that your design is=
 bad, I'm saying that it is unlikely
to be very good for testing if that ha=
s not been a design-goal (from
my experience)

About testing web-based appl=
ications and the effectiveness of unit
tests I would say that JUnit is equa=
lly appropriate for web, but, with
JUnit you test one class at the time (if=
 you do it interaction based)
or several classes from one class at the time=
 (if you are doing
statebased testing). In order to find bugs in your HTML =
etc you need
system tests and other tools (or add ons) to test that. (The e=
xample I
gave you was a unit-tested serverside with a manually tested
prese=
ntation layer). What you want to do though is to put as little
business log=
ic in your presentation layer as you can (that is put no
businesslogic ther=
e) so that all your businesslogic can be unit
tested. When you have that yo=
u find a lot fewer bugs in your
presentation-layer.

More and more tools ar=
e available testing web apps, I heard about but
never tried "selenium" try =
that one.  And I also recomend looking at
www.testdriven.com to see if you =
can find anything that suits you. But
regardless of wether you test the gen=
erated html or not you can still
rely on the fact that what is beneath your=
 presentation-layer works.

Sorry for the blah, blah response I easilly get=
 caught up in these
things :) I hope you could distill something useful fro=
m this massive
amount of text :)
